Unfortunately, the resulting algorithm does not always lead to the optimal policy as we explain next. In particular, we can solve the Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-values as

Qℳ,h⁢(sh,ah)subscript𝑄ℳℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝑎ℎ\displaystyle Q_{\mathcal{M},h}(s_{h},a_{h})italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =log⁡πℳ,h⁢(ah|sh)πref,h⁢(ah|sh)+η⁢log⁡𝔼πref,h⁢(ah′|sh)⁢exp⁡(Qℳ,h⁢(sh,ah′)η)absentsubscript𝜋ℳℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝜋refℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎ𝜂subscript𝔼subscript𝜋refℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑎′ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝑄ℳℎsubscript𝑠ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑎ℎ′𝜂\displaystyle=\log\frac{\pi_{\mathcal{M},h}(a_{h}|s_{h})}{\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}% (a_{h}|s_{h})}+\eta\log\mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}(a^{\prime}_{h}|s_{h})}% \exp\Big{(}\frac{Q_{\mathcal{M},h}(s_{h},a_{h}^{\prime})}{\eta}\Big{)}= roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + italic_η roman_log blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_exp ( divide start_ARG italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_η end_ARG ) (9)
=log⁡πℳ,h⁢(ah|sh)πref,h⁢(ah|sh)+Vℳ,h⁢(sh),absentsubscript𝜋ℳℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝜋refℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝑉ℳℎsubscript𝑠ℎ\displaystyle=\log\frac{\pi_{\mathcal{M},h}(a_{h}|s_{h})}{\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}% (a_{h}|s_{h})}+V_{\mathcal{M},h}(s_{h}),= roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where two equalities uses the definition of the optimal policy πℳ,hsubscript𝜋ℳℎ\pi_{\mathcal{M},h}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and V𝑉Vitalic_V-value Vℳ,hsubscript𝑉ℳℎV_{\mathcal{M},h}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in (7), respectively. Furthermore, by the definition of Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-values Qℳ,hsubscript𝑄ℳℎQ_{\mathcal{M},h}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in (6), we have

𝔼oh∼ℙh(⋅|sh,ah)⁢Vℳ,h+1⁢(sh+1)\displaystyle\mathbb{E}_{o_{h}\sim\mathbb{P}_{h}(\cdot|s_{h},a_{h})}V_{% \mathcal{M},h+1}(s_{h+1})blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =log⁡πℳ,h⁢(ah|sh)πref,h⁢(ah|sh)+Vℳ,h⁢(sh),if ⁢h≤H−1formulae-sequenceabsentsubscript𝜋ℳℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝜋refℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝑉ℳℎsubscript𝑠ℎif ℎ𝐻1\displaystyle=\log\frac{\pi_{\mathcal{M},h}(a_{h}|s_{h})}{\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}% (a_{h}|s_{h})}+V_{\mathcal{M},h}(s_{h}),\qquad\text{if }h\leq H-1= roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , if italic_h ≤ italic_H - 1 (10)
u⁢(sH,aH)𝑢subscript𝑠𝐻subscript𝑎𝐻\displaystyle u(s_{H},a_{H})italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =log⁡πℳ,H⁢(aH|sH)πref,H⁢(aH|sH)+Vℳ,H⁢(sH).absentsubscript𝜋ℳ𝐻conditionalsubscript𝑎𝐻subscript𝑠𝐻subscript𝜋ref𝐻conditionalsubscript𝑎𝐻subscript𝑠𝐻subscript𝑉ℳ𝐻subscript𝑠𝐻\displaystyle=\log\frac{\pi_{\mathcal{M},H}(a_{H}|s_{H})}{\pi_{\mathrm{ref},H}% (a_{H}|s_{H})}+V_{\mathcal{M},H}(s_{H}).= roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

Summing over h∈[H]ℎdelimited-[]𝐻h\in[H]italic_h ∈ [ italic_H ], we have

u⁢(sH,aH)𝑢subscript𝑠𝐻subscript𝑎𝐻\displaystyle u(s_{H},a_{H})italic_u ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =η⁢∑h=1Hlog⁡πℳ,h⁢(ah|sh)πref,h⁢(ah|sh)+∑h=1H[Vℳ,h⁢(sh)−𝔼oh∼ℙh(⋅|sh,ah)⁢Vℳ,h+1⁢(sh+1)]\displaystyle=\eta\sum_{h=1}^{H}\log\frac{\pi_{\mathcal{M},h}(a_{h}|s_{h})}{% \pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}(a_{h}|s_{h})}+\sum_{h=1}^{H}\Big{[}V_{\mathcal{M},h}(s_{h% })-\mathbb{E}_{o_{h}\sim\mathbb{P}_{h}(\cdot|s_{h},a_{h})}V_{\mathcal{M},h+1}(% s_{h+1})\Big{]}= italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] (11)
=η⁢∑h=1Hlog⁡πℳ,h⁢(ah|sh)πref,h⁢(ah|sh)⏟term (A)+Vℳ,1⁢(s1)⏟term (B)+∑h=1H−1[Vℳ,h+1⁢(sh+1)−𝔼oh∼ℙh(⋅|sh,ah)⁢Vℳ,h+1⁢(sh+1)]⏟term (C).\displaystyle=\underbrace{\eta\sum_{h=1}^{H}\log\frac{\pi_{\mathcal{M},h}(a_{h% }|s_{h})}{\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}(a_{h}|s_{h})}}_{\text{term $(A)$}}+\underbrace{% V_{\mathcal{M},1}(s_{1})}_{\text{term $(B)$}}+\underbrace{\sum_{h=1}^{H-1}\Big% {[}V_{\mathcal{M},h+1}(s_{h+1})-\mathbb{E}_{o_{h}\sim\mathbb{P}_{h}(\cdot|s_{h% },a_{h})}V_{\mathcal{M},h+1}(s_{h+1})\Big{]}}_{\text{term $(C)$}}.= under⏟ start_ARG italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT term ( italic_A ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + under⏟ start_ARG italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT term ( italic_B ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + under⏟ start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT term ( italic_C ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Here, term (A)𝐴(A)( italic_A ) is the counterpart of η⁢log⁡π⁢(a1|s1)πref⁢(a1|s1)𝜂𝜋conditionalsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑠1subscript𝜋refconditionalsubscript𝑎1subscript𝑠1\eta\log\frac{\pi(a_{1}|s_{1})}{\pi_{\mathrm{ref}}(a_{1}|s_{1})}italic_η roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG in the single-step DPO derivation and term (B)𝐵(B)( italic_B ) will be cancelled if we consider the reward difference of two trajectories with the same prompt s1=xsubscript𝑠1𝑥s_{1}=xitalic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x. Unfortunately, in practice, term (C)𝐶(C)( italic_C ) is typically not feasible to directly compute. Especially, some simple math with the Chebyshev’s Inequality leads to that with probability at least 0.90.90.90.9,

|C|≤4⁢[∑h=1H−1σh2]1/2,𝐶4superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptℎ1𝐻1superscriptsubscript𝜎ℎ212|C|\leq 4\left[\sum_{h=1}^{H-1}\sigma_{h}^{2}\right]^{1/2},| italic_C | ≤ 4 [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where σh2superscriptsubscript𝜎ℎ2\sigma_{h}^{2}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the conditional variance of Vℳ,h+1⁢(sh+1)−𝔼oh∼ℙh(⋅|sh,ah)⁢Vℳ,h+1⁢(sh+1)V_{\mathcal{M},h+1}(s_{h+1})-\mathbb{E}_{o_{h}\sim\mathbb{P}_{h}(\cdot|s_{h},a% _{h})}V_{\mathcal{M},h+1}(s_{h+1})italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ blackboard_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Therefore, the bias term (C)𝐶(C)( italic_C ) is related to the randomness of the external environment.

For most cases of tool-integrated LLMs for mathematical reasoning, i.e., the focus of this work, luckily the code execution result is determined by the history (the codes written by the LLMs). In other words, given the history shsubscript𝑠ℎs_{h}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the external observation is deterministic, which leads to term ⁢(C)=0term 𝐶0\text{term }(C)=0term ( italic_C ) = 0. Thus, with a dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D consisting of (x,τw,τl)𝑥superscript𝜏𝑤superscript𝜏𝑙(x,\tau^{w},\tau^{l})( italic_x , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), the following multi-turn DPO (M-DPO) loss can be adopted:

ℒM-DPO⁢(θ)=−∑(x,τw,τl)∈𝒟log⁡σ⁢(η⁢∑h=1H[log⁡πθ,h⁢(ahl|shl)πref,h⁢(ahl|shl)−log⁡πθ,h⁢(ahw|shw)πref,h⁢(ahw|shw)]),subscriptℒM-DPO𝜃subscript𝑥superscript𝜏𝑤superscript𝜏𝑙𝒟𝜎𝜂superscriptsubscriptℎ1𝐻delimited-[]subscript𝜋𝜃ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑙ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ𝑙subscript𝜋refℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑙ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ𝑙subscript𝜋𝜃ℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑤ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ𝑤subscript𝜋refℎconditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑤ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑠ℎ𝑤\mathcal{L}_{\textup{M-DPO}}(\theta)=-\sum_{(x,\tau^{w},\tau^{l})\in\mathcal{D% }}\log\sigma\Big{(}\eta\sum_{h=1}^{H}\Big{[}\log\frac{\pi_{\theta,h}(a^{l}_{h}% |s_{h}^{l})}{\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}(a^{l}_{h}|s_{h}^{l})}-\log\frac{\pi_{\theta,% h}(a^{w}_{h}|s_{h}^{w})}{\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}(a^{w}_{h}|s_{h}^{w})}\Big{]}\Big% {)},caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT M-DPO end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∈ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_σ ( italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG - roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG ] ) , (12)

We emphasize again that although the loss presented in (12) is identical to the one in (8), a rigorous derivation procedure (rather than a direct plug-in) is provided. To the best of our knowledge, (12) is new in the context of multi-turn reasoning task with external messages. In particular, it is noted that such a M-DPO loss is only valid upon deterministic transitions, i.e., term (C)=0𝐶0(C)=0( italic_C ) = 0.

Moreover, with (11) implying that with term (C)=0𝐶0(C)=0( italic_C ) = 0, the implicit reward is given by A=η⁢∑h=1Hlog⁡πh∗⁢(ah|sh)πref,h⁢(ah|sh)𝐴𝜂superscriptsubscriptℎ1𝐻subscriptsuperscript𝜋ℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝜋refℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎA=\eta\sum_{h=1}^{H}\log\frac{\pi^{*}_{h}(a_{h}|s_{h})}{\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}(a% _{h}|s_{h})}italic_A = italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG, a multi-turn version of KTO (Ethayarajh et al., 2024), denoted as M-KTO, can also be naturally derived:

ℒM-KTO⁢(θ)=𝔼x,y∼𝒟⁢[λy−v⁢(x,y)],subscriptℒM-KTO𝜃subscript𝔼similar-to𝑥𝑦𝒟delimited-[]subscript𝜆𝑦𝑣𝑥𝑦\mathcal{L}_{\textup{M-KTO}}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{x,y\sim\mathcal{D}}\big{[}% \lambda_{y}-v(x,y)\big{]},caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT M-KTO end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_y ∼ caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_v ( italic_x , italic_y ) ] , (13)

where

uθ⁢(x,y)subscript𝑢𝜃𝑥𝑦\displaystyle u_{\theta}(x,y)italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) =η⁢∑h=1Hlog⁡πu,h⁢(ah|sh)πref,h⁢(ah|sh),absent𝜂superscriptsubscriptℎ1𝐻subscript𝜋𝑢ℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝜋refℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎ\displaystyle=\eta\sum_{h=1}^{H}\log\frac{\pi_{u,h}(a_{h}|s_{h})}{\pi_{\mathrm% {ref},h}(a_{h}|s_{h})},= italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG ,
z0subscript𝑧0\displaystyle z_{0}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =𝔼x′∼𝒟,τ′∼πθ(⋅|x′)∑h=1HDKL(πθ(⋅|sh),πref(⋅|sh)),\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{x^{\prime}\sim\mathcal{D},\tau^{\prime}\sim\pi_{% \theta}(\cdot|x^{\prime})}\sum_{h=1}^{H}D_{\mathrm{KL}}\big{(}\pi_{\theta}(% \cdot|s_{h}),\pi_{\mathrm{ref}}(\cdot|s_{h})\big{)},= blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_D , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ,

and

v(x,y)={λ+⁢σ⁢(η⁢(uθ⁢(x,y)−z0))if ⁢y∼yd⁢e⁢s⁢i⁢r⁢a⁢b⁢l⁢e|xλ−⁢σ⁢(η⁢(z0−uθ⁢(x,y)))if ⁢y∼yu⁢n⁢d⁢e⁢s⁢i⁢r⁢a⁢b⁢l⁢e|x.v(x,y)=\left\{\begin{aligned} \lambda_{+}\sigma\big{(}\eta(u_{\theta}(x,y)-z_{% 0})\big{)}&\qquad\text{if }y\sim y_{desirable}|x\\ \lambda_{-}\sigma\big{(}\eta(z_{0}-u_{\theta}(x,y))\big{)}&\qquad\text{if }y% \sim y_{undesirable}|x\end{aligned}\right..italic_v ( italic_x , italic_y ) = { start_ROW start_CELL italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ ( italic_η ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) - italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_CELL start_CELL if italic_y ∼ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s italic_i italic_r italic_a italic_b italic_l italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_σ ( italic_η ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) ) ) end_CELL start_CELL if italic_y ∼ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_n italic_d italic_e italic_s italic_i italic_r italic_a italic_b italic_l italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_x end_CELL end_ROW .

Here λ+subscript𝜆\lambda_{+}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and λ−subscript𝜆\lambda_{-}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are two hyper-parameters. We notice that Mitra et al. (2024) developed an online iterative version of KTO for the CoT format reasoning task. Here we extend it to build the tool-integrated reasoning agent.

The above discussions, in particular, M-DPO and M-KTO losses provided in (12) and (13), are focused on deterministic observations due to the deterministic nature of tool-integrated LLMs for mathematical reasoning. In contrast, some other applications may encounter stochastic observations, e.g., multi-turn chats with the external message provided by a human or another LLM (Shani et al., 2024). In these scenarios, (12) is biased and cannot lead to the optimal policy since term ⁢(C)≠0term 𝐶0\text{term }(C)\neq 0term ( italic_C ) ≠ 0. Instead, one should first construct a value network based on the Bellman equations provided in (6) and (7), similar to the approach in Richemond et al. (2024). Subsequently, term ⁢(C)term 𝐶\text{term }(C)term ( italic_C ) can be estimated using Monte-Carlo methods and serve as an adaptive margin in the preference training. Particularly, the distinctions between direct preference learning algorithms and classical deep RL methods become less clear. The exploration of this more complex algorithm and its application to general multi-turn learning scenarios is left for future research.

We note that the MDP formulation above and related discussions have been previously derived by Zhong et al. (2024); Rafailov et al. (2024); Xie et al. (2024a) in the context of either token-wise MDP or more general MDP with deterministic transition but their focuses are all on the single-turn chat tasks. Although the mathematical formulations appear similar, our primary focus lies on tool-integrated reasoning tasks that incorporate additional external messages {oh}h=1H−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑜ℎℎ1𝐻1\{o_{h}\}_{h=1}^{H-1}{ italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

2.3 Learning with Online Iterative Training

In the literature of direct preference learning, a long line of work shows that the online single-turn RLHF significantly outperforms their offline counterpart, both in the literature of direct preference learning (Xiong et al., ; Ye et al., 2024; Guo et al., 2024b; Rosset et al., 2024; Dong et al., 2024; Tajwar et al., 2024) and DRL-based approach or rejection sampling fine-tuning (Bai et al., 2022; Ouyang et al., 2022; Touvron et al., 2023). Motivated by these successes, we propose to further incorporate online interactive learning to the multi-turn RLHF studied in this work. In the following, we illustrate the proposed ideas from mainly two aspects: two learning objectives and one unified algorithmic framework.

Learning objective.

We consider two different learning objectives. The first one is the KL-regularized target:

maxπ𝔼x∼d0𝔼ah∼π(⋅|sh),oh∼ℙh∗(⋅|sh,ah)[u∗(x,y)−η∑h=1HDKL(π(⋅|sh),π0(⋅|sh))],\max_{\pi}\mathbb{E}_{x\sim d_{0}}\mathbb{E}_{a_{h}\sim\pi(\cdot|s_{h}),o_{h}% \sim\mathbb{P}^{*}_{h}(\cdot|s_{h},a_{h})}\Big{[}u^{*}(x,y)-\eta\sum_{h=1}^{H}% D_{\mathrm{KL}}\big{(}\pi(\cdot|s_{h}),\pi_{0}(\cdot|s_{h})\big{)}\Big{]},roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∼ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_π ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) - italic_η ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) ] , (14)

i.e., maxπ⁡J⁢(π;ℳ∗,π0)subscript𝜋𝐽𝜋superscriptℳsubscript𝜋0\max_{\pi}J(\pi;\mathcal{M}^{*},\pi_{0})roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J ( italic_π ; caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where ℳ∗=(𝒮,𝒜,H,ℙ∗,d0,u∗)superscriptℳ𝒮𝒜𝐻superscriptℙsubscript𝑑0superscript𝑢\mathcal{M}^{*}=({\mathcal{S}},\mathcal{A},H,\mathbb{P}^{*},d_{0},u^{*})caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( caligraphic_S , caligraphic_A , italic_H , blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the groundtruth environment and π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the initial policy (e.g., from SFT) that RLHF starts from. This target is widely adopted in practice (Christiano et al., 2017; Ouyang et al., 2022; Bai et al., 2022; Rafailov et al., 2023; Dong et al., 2024) and requires us to search for the optimal policy only at a fixed KL ball centered at the SFT policy π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Xiong et al., ; Ye et al., 2024; Xie et al., 2024a).

In contrast, the second one is the non-regularized target, i.e., directly optimizing the reward:

maxπ⁡𝔼x∼d0⁢𝔼ah∼π(⋅|sh),oh∼ℙh∗(⋅|sh,ah)⁢[u∗⁢(x,y)].\max_{\pi}\mathbb{E}_{x\sim d_{0}}\mathbb{E}_{a_{h}\sim\pi(\cdot|s_{h}),o_{h}% \sim\mathbb{P}^{*}_{h}(\cdot|s_{h},a_{h})}\big{[}u^{*}(x,y)\big{]}.roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∼ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_π ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) ] . (15)

This target is the standard one in canonical RL studies (Sutton and Barto, 2018). One motivation for this target is that in the reasoning task, the reward function is more interpretable (e.g. final result checking) compared to the chat task.

Additionally, we note that a stronger KL regularization in the target (14) is known to be beneficial for mitigating over-fitting issue and forgetting on the out-of-domain tasks (Gao et al., 2023b; Lin et al., 2023; Coste et al., 2023). On the other hand, (15) allows the model to move more far away, thus achieving a better in-domain performance. Thus, from one perspective, the choice between the above two targets can be viewed as a tradeoff between out-of-domain and in-domain performances. This intuition is also verified by later experiments, where optimizing the second target in (15) leads to better performance on in-domain test sets. In the rest of this section, we discuss two learning objectives to fully develop the multi-turn preference learning framework. We also conduct an ablation study on these objectives in the experimental section.

Algorithmic framework.

We present a general online iterative algorithmic framework in Algorithm 1. This framework is termed as Online Iterative Multi-turn Gibbs Sampling from Human Feedback (M-GSHF) to highlight the online iterative training process and the optimal condition derived in (7) that the optimal policy is a layer-wise Gibbs distribution, which generalizes the bandit formulation in Xiong et al. . Specifically, starting from π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, at each iteration, we first collect a pair of trajectories by the current policy pair, where the preference signal is also revealed according to Definition 1. Then, we update our policy pair given the data collected so far and the next iteration begins. We now discuss some features of the framework as follows.

Policy choice for exploration-exploitation trade-off. We update our behavior policies in a non-symmetric way. The first agent, which aims to extract the historical information we have gathered so far, planning with respect to the empirically best model on the historical dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D to get πt1superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡1\pi_{t}^{1}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where the planning algorithms have been discussed in Section 2.2, e.g., optimizing the M-DPO or M-KTO loss in (12) or (13). However, it is widely recognized in RL studies (Sutton and Barto, 2018; Auer et al., 2002) that simply exploiting the historical data via following the empirically best model is not sufficient to obtain a good final policy, while it is also required to explore the environment so that new information can be collected to facilitate subsequent learning, i.e., the exploration-exploitation tradeoff. While the main agent targeting exploitation, we design the second agent, in contrast, to strategically incorporate the uncertainty of the future relative to πt1superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡1\pi_{t}^{1}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT given the historical information we collect so far into its policy choice. We call the policy of the second agent πt2superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡2\pi_{t}^{2}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as an exploration policy because it serves to explore the underlying environment and facilitate the first agent’s learning. In practice, this principle of exploration is generally interpreted as maximizing the difference between the two behavior policies or increasing the diversity of the collected data. We summarize some popular heuristic exploration policy adopted in the online iterative RLHF practice:

  • •

    Mixture sampling: in the Claude project (Anthropic, 2023), the authors choose to use the checkpoints from different training steps to collect data;

  • •

    Inference parameters tuning: in the LLaMA project (Touvron et al., 2023), the authors carefully tune the sampling temperature to balance data diversity and data quality;

  • •

    West-of-n sampling: Xu et al. (2023); Hoang Tran (2024); Pace et al. (2024); Dong et al. (2024) samples n responses per prompt and extract the best one and the worst one (based on some ranking criteria) to construct a preference pair.

We will explore the mixture sampling in the experimental section and also provide a theoretical justification in the next subsection.

Reference model choice for controlling regularization level. Despite two different learning targets are discussed in (14) and (15) seperately, we note that one general algorithmic framework can be adopted with the reference model choice taking as a hyper-parameter to control the regularization level and account for the two targets:

  • •

    KL-regularized target in (14): if we fix the reference model as the initial policy, i.e., πt,ref=π0,∀t∈[T]formulae-sequencesubscript𝜋𝑡refsubscript𝜋0for-all𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\pi_{t,\mathrm{ref}}=\pi_{0},\forall t\in[T]italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ], we always search the optimal policy within the KL ball centered at π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and thus optimize the KL-regularized target.

  • •

    Non-regularized target in (15): in contrast, inspired by the mirror descent (Nemirovskij and Yudin, 1983), if we update the reference policy every iteration to be the policy learned in the last iteration, i.e., πt,ref=πt−11,∀t∈[T]formulae-sequencesubscript𝜋𝑡refsubscriptsuperscript𝜋1𝑡1for-all𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\pi_{t,\mathrm{ref}}=\pi^{1}_{t-1},\forall t\in[T]italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ], the cumulative update can make the model to move away from the original π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (while a constraint is made on the per-iteration update magnitude) and we thus optimize the non-regularized target.

A graphical illustration is provided in Figure 2 to facilitate the understanding.

2.4 Theoretical Results

In this section, we show that the multi-turn RLHF problem can be solved in a statistically efficient manner under standard assumptions in learning theory literature. In particular, for generality, we target the most challenging scenario with stochastic and unknown transitions, while as aforementioned, multi-turn mathematical reasoning with external tools falls into an relatively easier regime with deterministic transitions. Here we mostly studies the KL-regularized target due to the lack of theoretical research on it. The other target of optimizing the rewards has been theoretically studied in Wang et al. (2023b) while the techniques of analyzing mirror-descent-style algorithm and corresponding guarantees have also be developed in Cai et al. (2020), which can be migrated to considering preference feedbacks. Also, to ease the presentation, we consider the scenario with batch size m=1𝑚1m=1italic_m = 1, while the results can be easily generalized to large batches.

First, to measure the online learning process, we define the optimal policy as

π∗:=argmaxπJ⁢(π):=J⁢(π;ℳ∗,π0),assignsuperscript𝜋subscriptargmax𝜋𝐽𝜋assign𝐽𝜋superscriptℳsubscript𝜋0\pi^{*}:=\mathop{\mathrm{argmax}}_{\pi}J(\pi):=J(\pi;\mathcal{M}^{*},\pi_{0}),italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_argmax start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J ( italic_π ) := italic_J ( italic_π ; caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (16)

and introduce the standard notion of regret as

Reg⁢(T):=∑t∈[T]J⁢(π∗)−J⁢(πt1),assignReg𝑇subscript𝑡delimited-[]𝑇𝐽superscript𝜋𝐽subscriptsuperscript𝜋1𝑡\text{Reg}(T):=\sum_{t\in[T]}J(\pi^{*})-J(\pi^{1}_{t}),Reg ( italic_T ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_J ( italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_J ( italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (17)

which represents the cumulative performance loss over T𝑇Titalic_T steps comparing the learned policies [πt1]t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡1𝑡1𝑇[\pi_{t}^{1}]_{t=1}^{T}[ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT against the optimal policy π∗superscript𝜋\pi^{*}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In addition, we consider that a bounded u∗⁢(x,y)∈[0,B]superscript𝑢𝑥𝑦0𝐵u^{*}(x,y)\in[0,B]italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) ∈ [ 0 , italic_B ] for all (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y ) to maintain a reasonable utillity regime. Also, it is assumed that we have accesses to the following policy improvement oracle, that is analogue to the one considered in Xiong et al. .

Definition 3 (Policy Improvement Oracle).

For any model ℳ=(𝒮,𝒜,H,ℙ,d0,u)ℳ𝒮𝒜𝐻ℙsubscript𝑑0𝑢\mathcal{M}=({\mathcal{S}},\mathcal{A},H,\mathbb{P},d_{0},u)caligraphic_M = ( caligraphic_S , caligraphic_A , italic_H , blackboard_P , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u ) and a reference function πrefsubscript𝜋ref\pi_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we can compute the optimal policy associated with the model [πℳ,h]h=1Hsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜋ℳℎℎ1𝐻[\pi_{\mathcal{M},h}]_{h=1}^{H}[ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iteratively as in (7).

The overall algorithm, i.e., the theoretical version of online iterative M-GSHF, is also summarized in Algorithm 1. At each round t𝑡titalic_t, with 𝒟=∪i=1t−1𝒟i𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡1subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}=\cup_{i=1}^{t-1}\mathcal{D}_{i}caligraphic_D = ∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the aggregated dataset, it starts with performing a maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) of the reward function u∗superscript𝑢u^{*}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over a set 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}caligraphic_U, whose elements are bounded in [0,B]0𝐵[0,B][ 0 , italic_B ], as

u^t=argmaxu^∈𝒰Lt⁢(u^):=∑(x,τ1,τ2,z)∈∪i=1t−1𝒟i[z⁢log⁡(σ⁢(u^⁢(τ1)−u^⁢(τ2)))+(1−z)⁢log⁡(σ⁢(u^⁢(τ2)−u^⁢(τ1)))],subscript^𝑢𝑡subscriptargmax^𝑢𝒰subscript𝐿𝑡^𝑢assignsubscript𝑥superscript𝜏1superscript𝜏2𝑧superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡1subscript𝒟𝑖delimited-[]𝑧𝜎^𝑢superscript𝜏1^𝑢superscript𝜏21𝑧𝜎^𝑢superscript𝜏2^𝑢superscript𝜏1\hat{u}_{t}=\mathop{\mathrm{argmax}}_{\hat{u}\in\mathcal{U}}L_{t}(\hat{u}):=% \sum_{(x,\tau^{1},\tau^{2},z)\in\cup_{i=1}^{t-1}\mathcal{D}_{i}}\Big{[}z\log(% \sigma(\hat{u}(\tau^{1})-\hat{u}(\tau^{2})))+(1-z)\log(\sigma(\hat{u}(\tau^{2}% )-\hat{u}(\tau^{1})))\Big{]},over^ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_argmax start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_z ) ∈ ∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_z roman_log ( italic_σ ( over^ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - over^ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ) + ( 1 - italic_z ) roman_log ( italic_σ ( over^ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - over^ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ) ] , (18)

and also an MLE of the transition kernel ℙ∗superscriptℙ\mathbb{P}^{*}blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over a set 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P as

ℙ^t=argmaxℙ^∈𝒫Lt⁢(ℙ^):=∑(π,τ)∈∪i=1t−1𝒟ilog⁡ℙ^π⁢(τ),subscript^ℙ𝑡subscriptargmax^ℙ𝒫subscript𝐿𝑡^ℙassignsubscript𝜋𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡1subscript𝒟𝑖superscript^ℙ𝜋𝜏\hat{\mathbb{P}}_{t}=\mathop{\mathrm{argmax}}_{\hat{\mathbb{P}}\in\mathcal{P}}% L_{t}(\hat{\mathbb{P}}):=\sum_{(\pi,\tau)\in\cup_{i=1}^{t-1}\mathcal{D}_{i}}% \log\hat{\mathbb{P}}^{\pi}(\tau),over^ start_ARG blackboard_P end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_argmax start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG blackboard_P end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG blackboard_P end_ARG ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_π , italic_τ ) ∈ ∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log over^ start_ARG blackboard_P end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) , (19)

where ℙπ⁢(τ)superscriptℙ𝜋𝜏\mathbb{P}^{\pi}(\tau)blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_π end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_τ ) denotes the probability of trajectory τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ under policy π𝜋\piitalic_π and transition kernel ℙℙ\mathbb{P}blackboard_P. With the obtained model ℳ^t=(u^t,ℙ^t)subscript^ℳ𝑡subscript^𝑢𝑡subscript^ℙ𝑡\hat{\mathcal{M}}_{t}=(\hat{u}_{t},\hat{\mathbb{P}}_{t})over^ start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( over^ start_ARG italic_u end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG blackboard_P end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the Oracle defined in Definition 3 is called with the reference policy πrefsubscript𝜋ref\pi_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT set as the initial policy π0subscript𝜋0\pi_{0}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, whose output is adopted as the main policy πt1subscriptsuperscript𝜋1𝑡\pi^{1}_{t}italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Then, we specify how to choose a theoretically sound exploration policy πt2superscriptsubscript𝜋𝑡2\pi_{t}^{2}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The previous work of Xiong et al. on single-turn RLHF has demonstrated the intuition that the exploration policy should be in charge of collecting information of the uncertain parts of the environment ℳℳ\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M, which is thus often selected to maximize one uncertainty measurement. In the multi-turn RLHF setup considered in this work, the following proposition serves as the cornerstone to find a suitable uncertainty measurement to decide the exploration policy. In particular, we can observe that the optimal policy is parameterized by the optimal Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-function. If a different set of Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-function is adopted for policy parameterization, we can bound its performance as follows.

Proposition 1 (Value Decomposition Lemma for KL-regularized MDP).

If considering a set of Q𝑄Qitalic_Q-functions [Q^h]h=1Hsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝑄ℎℎ1𝐻[\hat{Q}_{h}]_{h=1}^{H}[ over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a reference policy πrefsubscript𝜋ref\pi_{\mathrm{ref}}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with the induced policy π^^𝜋\hat{\pi}over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG as

π^h⁢(ah|sh)∝πref,h⁢(ah|sh)⋅exp⁡(Q^h⁢(sh,ah)/η),proportional-tosubscript^𝜋ℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎ⋅subscript𝜋refℎconditionalsubscript𝑎ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript^𝑄ℎsubscript𝑠ℎsubscript𝑎ℎ𝜂\displaystyle\hat{\pi}_{h}(a_{h}|s_{h})\propto\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}(a_{h}|s_{h}% )\cdot\exp\left(\hat{Q}_{h}(s_{h},a_{h})/\eta\right),over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∝ italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⋅ roman_exp ( over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_η ) ,

and the corresponding set of V𝑉Vitalic_V-functions [V^h]h=1Hsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript^𝑉ℎℎ1𝐻[\hat{V}_{h}]_{h=1}^{H}[ over^ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_H end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as

V^h(sh)=𝔼ah∼π^h(⋅|sh)[Q^h(sh,ah)]−ηDKL(π^h(⋅|sh),πref,h(⋅|sh)),V^H+1(sH+1)=0,\displaystyle\hat{V}_{h}(s_{h})=\mathbb{E}_{a_{h}\sim\hat{\pi}_{h}(\cdot|s_{h}% )}\left[\hat{Q}_{h}(s_{h},a_{h})\right]-\eta D_{\mathrm{KL}}(\hat{\pi}_{h}(% \cdot|s_{h}),\pi_{\mathrm{ref},h}(\cdot|s_{h})),\qquad\hat{V}_{H+1}(s_{H+1})=0,over^ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ over^ start_ARG italic_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ] - italic_η italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_KL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ref , italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , over^ start_ARG italic_V end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 ,

for any comparator policy π𝜋\piitalic_π, it holds that

where the expectation 𝔼d0,π,ℙ∗subscript𝔼subscript𝑑0𝜋superscriptℙ\mathbb{E}_{d_{0},\pi,\mathbb{P}^{*}}blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_π , blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is with respect to the prompt and response (i.e., the trajectory) generated following d0,ℙ∗subscript𝑑0superscriptℙd_{0},\mathbb{P}^{*}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , blackboard_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and π𝜋\piitalic_π.
